title: 2008 Summer Olympics
text:
The 2008 Summer Olympics (), officially the Games of the XXIX Olympiad () and also known as Beijing 2008 (), were an international <a href="multisport%20event">multisport event</a> held from 8 to 24 August 2008 in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="China">China</a>. A total of 10,942 athletes from 204 <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a>s (NOCs) competed in 28 sports and 302 events, one event more than those scheduled for the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a>. This was the first time China had hosted the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>, and the third time the <a href="Summer%20Olympic%20Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> had been held in <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a>, following the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Olympics</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, Japan, and the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Olympics</a> in <a href="Seoul">Seoul</a>, South Korea. These were also the second Summer <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a> to be held in a <a href="communist%20state">communist state</a>, the first being the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a> in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> (with venues in <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>, and <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>).
Beijing was <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20bids">awarded the 2008 Games</a> over four competitors on 13 July 2001, having won a majority of votes from members of the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) after two rounds of voting. The <a href="Government%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">Government of the People's Republic of China</a> promoted the 2008 Games and invested heavily in new facilities and transport systems. 37 venues were used to host the events, including twelve constructed specifically for the 2008 Games. The <a href="Equestrian%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">equestrian events</a> were held in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>, making these the third Olympics for which the events were held under the jurisdiction of two different NOCs. The <a href="Sailing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">sailing events</a> were contested in <a href="Qingdao">Qingdao</a>, while the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">football events</a> took place across several different cities.
The official logo for the 2008 Games, titled "<a href="Dancing%20Beijing">Dancing Beijing</a> "(舞动北京), created by <a href="Guo%20Chunning">Guo Chunning</a> (郭春宁), featured the Chinese character for "capital" (, stylized into the shape of a human being) in reference to the host city. The 2008 Olympics were watched by 3.5 billion people worldwide, and featured the longest distance for an Olympic Torch relay. The 2008 Games also set <a href="World%20and%20Olympic%20records%20set%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">numerous world and Olympic records</a>, and were the most expensive Summer Olympics of all time, and the second most expensive overall, after the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics">2014 Winter Games</a> in <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a>. The <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">opening ceremony</a> was lauded by spectators and numerous international presses as spectacular, spellbinding, and by many accounts, "the greatest ever in the history of Olympics". Beijing will host the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>, making it the first city ever to host both the Summer and Winter Games.
An unprecedented 87 countries won at least one medal during the 2008 Games. Host nation <a href="China%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">China</a> won the most gold medals (48), and became the seventh different team to top an overall Summer Olympics medal tally, winning a total of 100 medals overall. The <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">United States</a> placed second in the gold medal tally but won the highest number of medals overall (112). The third place in the gold medal tally was achieved by <a href="Russia%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Russia</a>.
These also became the first Olympic Games involving <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> and <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> (as a separated states in 2006) and <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a> (<a href="Nepalese%20Civil%20War">as a republic</a>, also in 2006), as well as the last Olympic Games involving <a href="History%20of%20Libya%20under%20Muammar%20Gaddafi">Libyan Arab Jamahiriya</a> (dissolved in 2011) and <a href="Netherlands%20Antilles">Netherlands Antilles</a> (dissolved in 2010). These games saw the return of the Summer Olympics to Asia after 20 years, the last being 1988 in Seoul.
Organization.
Bid.
Beijing was elected as the host city for the 2008 Summer Olympics on 13 July 2001, during the <a href="List%20of%20IOC%20meetings">112th</a> <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">IOC</a> Session in Moscow, defeating bids from Toronto, Paris, <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, and <a href="Osaka">Osaka</a>. Prior to the session, five other cities (<a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>, <a href="Havana">Havana</a>, <a href="Kuala%20Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a>, and <a href="Seville">Seville</a>) had submitted bids to the IOC, but failed to make the short list chosen by the IOC Executive Committee in 2000. After the first round of voting, Beijing held a significant lead over the other four candidates. Osaka received only six votes and was eliminated. In the second round, Beijing was supported by a <a href="majority">majority</a> of voters, eliminating the need for subsequent rounds. Toronto's bid was its fifth failure since 1960 (failed bids for 1960, 1964, 1976 and 1996 Games, losing to Rome, Tokyo, Montreal and Atlanta).
Members of the IOC did not disclose their votes, but news reports speculated that broad international support led to China's selection, especially from developing nations that had received assistance from China to construct stadiums. The size of China, its increased enforcement of doping controls, and sympathy concerning its loss of the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics">2000 Summer Olympics</a> to Sydney were all factors in the decision. Eight years earlier, Beijing had led every round of <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics%20bids">voting</a> for the 2000 Summer Olympics before losing to Sydney by two votes in the final round.
Human rights concerns expressed by <a href="Amnesty%20International">Amnesty International</a> and politicians in both Europe and the United States were considered by the delegates, according to IOC Executive Director François Carrard. Carrard and others suggested that the selection might lead to improvements in human rights in China. In addition, many IOC delegates who had formerly been athletes expressed concern about heat and air quality during the Games, considering the high levels of air pollution in Beijing. China outlined plans to address these environmental concerns in its bid application.
Costs.
The "Oxford Olympics Study 2016" estimates the outturn cost of the Beijing 2008 Summer Olympics at US$6.8 billion in 2015-dollars and cost overrun at 2% in real terms. This includes sports-related costs only, that is, (i) "operational costs" incurred by the organizing committee to stage the Games, e.g., expenditures for technology, transportation, workforce, administration, security, catering, ceremonies, and medical services, and (ii) "direct capital costs" incurred by the host city and country or private investors to build the competition venues, the Olympic village, international broadcast center, and media and press center, which are required to host the Games. Indirect capital costs are "not" included, such as for road, rail, or airport infrastructure, or for hotel upgrades or other business investment incurred in preparation for the Games but not directly related to staging the Games. The Beijing Olympics' cost of US$6.8 billion compares with costs of US$4.6 billion for Rio 2016 and US$15 billion for London 2012. The average cost for the Summer Games since 1960 is US$5.2 billion.
On 6 March 2009, the <a href="Beijing%20Organizing%20Committee%20for%20the%20Olympic%20Games">Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games</a> reported that total spending on the Games was "generally as much as that of the Athens 2004 Olympic Games", which was equivalent to about US$15 billion. They went on to claim that surplus revenues from the Games would exceed the original target of $16 million. Other reports, however, estimated the total costs from $40 to $44 billion, which would make the Games "far and away the most expensive ever".
Its budget was later exceeded by the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a>, which suffered from major <a href="cost%20overrun">cost overrun</a>s; the 2014 Winter Olympics costed roughly US$50 billion in private and public funding.
Venues.
By May 2007 the construction of all 31 Beijing-based Olympic Games venues had begun. The Chinese government renovated and constructed six venues outside Beijing, and constructed 59 training facilities. The largest structures built were the <a href="Beijing%20National%20Stadium">Beijing National Stadium</a>, <a href="Beijing%20National%20Indoor%20Stadium">Beijing National Indoor Stadium</a>, <a href="Beijing%20National%20Aquatics%20Center">Beijing National Aquatics Center</a>, <a href="Peking%20University%20Gymnasium">Peking University Gymnasium</a>, <a href="Olympic%20Green%20Convention%20Center">Olympic Green Convention Center</a>, <a href="Olympic%20Green">Olympic Green</a>, and <a href="Beijing%20Wukesong%20Culture%20%26amp%3B%20Sports%20Center">Beijing Wukesong Culture & Sports Center</a>. Almost 85% of the construction budget for the six main venues was funded by $2.1 billion (<a href="Renminbi">RMB¥</a>17.4 billion) in corporate bids and tenders. Investments were expected from corporations seeking ownership rights after the Olympics. Some events were held outside Beijing, namely <a href="Football%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">football</a> in <a href="Qinhuangdao">Qinhuangdao</a>, <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="Shenyang">Shenyang</a>, and <a href="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>; <a href="Sailing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">sailing</a> in <a href="Qingdao">Qingdao</a>; and, because of the "uncertainties of equine diseases and major difficulties in establishing a disease-free zone", the <a href="Equestrian%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">equestrian</a> events were held in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>.
The showpiece of the 2008 Summer Olympics was the Beijing National Stadium, nicknamed "The Bird's Nest" because of its nest-like skeletal structure. The stadium hosted both the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">opening</a> and <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20closing%20ceremony">closing</a> ceremonies, as well as the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">athletics</a> competition. Construction of the venue began on 24 December 2003. The <a href="Guangdong%20Olympic%20Stadium">Guangdong Olympic Stadium</a> was originally planned, constructed, and completed in 2001 to help host the Games, but a decision was made to construct a new stadium in Beijing. In 2001, the city held a bidding process to select the best arena design. Several criteria were required of each design, including flexibility for post-Olympics use, a <a href="retractable%20roof">retractable roof</a>, and low maintenance costs. The entry list was narrowed to thirteen final designs. The bird's nest model submitted by architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron in collaboration with Li Xinggang of China Architecture Design and Research Group (CADG) was selected as the top design by both a professional panel and by a broader audience during a public exhibition. The selection of the design became official in April 2003. Construction of the stadium was a joint venture among the original designers, project architect Stefan Marbach, artist <a href="Ai%20Weiwei">Ai Weiwei</a>, and a group of CADG architects led by Li Xinggang. Its $423 million cost was funded by the state-owned corporate conglomerate <a href="CITIC">CITIC</a> and the Beijing State-Owned Assets Management Company.
The 2008 Beijing Olympics caused traditional <a href="Hutong">Hutong</a> neighborhoods to be cleared to construct modern Olympic stadiums. In an effort to ensure success for the Games, the government invested billions in building new infrastructure, although clearance to tiny, outdated neighborhoods in Beijing called hutongs resulted (Petrun). Jim Yardley, a "<a href="New%20York%20Times">New York Times</a>" reporter interviewed Pan Jinyu, a 64-year-old local resident: "They [the government] don't want foreigners to see this scarred old face." Feng Shuqin and her husband, Zheng Zhanlin, had lived in their house for 50 years, and the family had owned the property before the Communists took control in 1949. The government, trying to clear the area, offered them to move with a compensatory sum of US$175,000, but the family insisted the land was worth US$1.4 million (Yardley). Michael Meyer, an American who lives in the hutongs, reported that 500,000 residents were relocated from their homes before the Olympics began (Meyer).
Transport.
To prepare for Olympic visitors, Beijing's transportation infrastructure was expanded. <a href="Beijing%20Capital%20International%20Airport">Beijing's airport</a> underwent a major renovation with the addition of the new Terminal 3, designed by architect <a href="Norman%20Foster%2C%20Baron%20Foster%20of%20Thames%20Bank">Norman Foster</a>. Within the city itself, <a href="Beijing%20Subway">Beijing's subway</a> was doubled in capacity and length, with the addition of seven lines and 80 stations to the previously existing four lines and 64 stations. Included in this expansion was a new link connecting to the city's airport. A fleet of thousands of buses, minibuses, and official cars transported spectators, athletes, and officials between venues.
In an effort to improve air quality, the city placed restrictions on construction sites and gas stations and limited the use of commercial and passenger vehicles in Beijing. From 20 July through 20 September, passenger vehicle restrictions were placed on alternative days depending on the terminal digit of the car's license plate. It was anticipated that this measure would take 45% of Beijing's 3.3 million cars off the streets. The boosted public transport network was expected to absorb the demand created by these restrictions and the influx of visitors, which was estimated at more than 4 million additional passengers per day.
Marketing.
The 2008 Summer Olympics emblem was known as <a href="Dancing%20Beijing">Dancing Beijing</a>. The emblem combined a traditional Chinese red seal and a representation of the <a href="Chinese%20calligraphy">calligraphic</a> <a href="Chinese%20character">character</a> for "capital" (<a href="wikt%3A%E4%BA%AC">京</a>, also the second character of Beijing's Chinese name) with athletic features. The open arms of the calligraphic word symbolized the invitation from China to the world to share in its culture. <a href="IOC%20president">IOC president</a> <a href="Jacques%20Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a> was rather pleased with the emblem, saying, "Your new emblem immediately conveys the awesome beauty and power of China which are embodied in your heritage and your people."
The official motto for the 2008 Olympics was "One World, One Dream" (). It called upon the whole world to join in the Olympic spirit and build a better future for humanity, and was chosen from over 210,000 entries submitted from around the world. Following the announcement of the motto, the phrase was used by international advocates of <a href="Tibetan%20secession">Tibetan secession</a>. Banners reading "One World, One Dream, Free Tibet" were unfurled from various structures around the globe in the lead up to the Beijing Olympics, such as from the <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> <a href="Golden%20Gate%20Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a> and the <a href="Sydney%20Opera%20House">Sydney Opera House</a> in Australia.
The <a href="mascot">mascot</a>s of Beijing 2008 were the five <a href="Fuwa">Fuwa</a>, each of which represented both a color of the <a href="Olympic%20flag">Olympic rings</a> and a symbol of Chinese culture. In 2006, the <a href="Beijing%20Organizing%20Committee%20for%20the%20Olympic%20Games">Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games</a> released <a href="pictogram">pictogram</a>s of 35 Olympic disciplines (however, for some multidiscipline sports such as cycling, a single pictogram was released). This set of sport icons was named "the beauty of seal characters", because of each pictogram's likeness to Chinese <a href="seal%20script">seal script</a>.
Uniforms and Officials.
On July 17, 2008, the uniforms for the hostesses and flag raisers were unveiled at 798 Art Factory in Beijing.
Multiple designs were used for different events, picked from around 300 submitted designs to the BOCOG, with three overall designs use for a single event; one for tray holders, one for dignitary escorts, and one for athlete escorts. The hostesses themselves had to meet several criteria: they had to be university educated, between the ages of 18 and 24, around 1.68-1.78 metres in height, among other requirements. They also had to go through training for synchronised movements and etiquette.
The uniforms for the flag bearers were also unveiled on the same day as the hostesses.
Around 150 non-uniformed personnel from the <a href="Beijing%20Garrison%20Honor%20Guard%20Battalion">Beijing Garrison Honor Guard Battalion</a> and 44 personnel from the Flag Guard at <a href="Tsinghua%20University">Tsinghua University</a> were selected for the flag bearer role. In addition, personnel from the Qingdao Provincial Armed Police Corps and the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Police%20Force">Hong Kong Police Force</a> were also selected for flag bearer duties at the sailing and equestrian events, respectively.
The flag bearers had to go through rigorous training, which included elements like identifying around 200 different national flags, timing the raising of a flag to a national anthem, as well as marching and body movements. These flag bearers were also used for test events in the lead up to the Beijing Olympic Games.
Several designs were used for different ceremonies. The uniforms for Olympic Village welcoming ceremonies included black boots, white gloves, white pants, a black belt, a black cap and a white buttoned shirt. The uniforms for medal ceremonies included white shoes, white pants, white gloves and a white buttoned shirt with a round collar. Blue calligraphy designs were incorporated onto the pants and shirt collars, with the "Beijing 2008" text on the front of the shirt pocket.
For the pre-Olympic test events, the flag bearer uniform included a relatively similar design, except that the shirt was replaced with a gold-button suit-vest, an inner white shirt donned with a gold tie and gold belt, and the shoes' color changed from white to black.
Look of the Games.
 Four <a href="primary%20colors">primary colors</a> were used in the branding of the Games: China Red, Yellow, Lime Green, and Sky Blue, which were used to represent China, sun, land, and water, respectively.
Media coverage.
The 2008 Games were the first to be produced and broadcast entirely in <a href="High-definition%20television">high definition</a> by the host broadcaster. In comparison, American broadcaster <a href="NBC">NBC broadcast</a> only half of the Turin <a href="2006%20Winter%20Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> in HD. In their bid for the Olympic Games in 2001, Beijing stated to the Olympic Evaluation Commission that there would be "no restrictions on media reporting and movement of journalists up to and including the Olympic Games." However, some media outlets claimed that organizers ultimately failed to live up to this commitment.
According to Nielsen Media Research, 4.7 billion viewers worldwide tuned in to some of the television coverage, one-fifth larger than the 3.9 billion who watched the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens. American broadcaster NBC produced only two hours of online streaming video for the 2006 Winter Games but produced approximately 2,200 hours of coverage for the 2008 Summer Games. <a href="CNN">CNN</a> reported that, for the first time, "live online video rights in some markets for the Olympics have been separately negotiated, not part of the overall 'broadcast rights.'" The new media of the <a href="digital%20economy">digital economy</a> was said to be growing "nine times faster than the rest of the advertising market."
The international <a href="European%20Broadcasting%20Union">European Broadcasting Union</a> (EBU) provided live coverage and highlights of all arenas only for certain territories on their website, Eurovisionsports.tv. Many national broadcasters likewise restricted the viewing of online events to their domestic audiences. The General National Copyright Administration of China announced that "individual ("sic") and websites will face fines as high as 100,000 <a href="Chinese%20yuan">yuan</a> for uploading recordings of Olympic Games video to the internet", part of an extensive campaign to protect the pertinent intellectual property rights. The Olympic Committee also set up a separate YouTube channel at Beijing 2008.
Theme song.
The theme song of the 2008 Summer Olympics was <a href="You%20and%20Me%20%28Olympic%20theme%20song%29">"You and Me,"</a> which was composed by <a href="Chen%20Qigang">Chen Qigang</a>, the musical director of the opening ceremony. It was performed during the opening ceremony by Chinese singer <a href="Liu%20Huan">Liu Huan</a> and British singer <a href="Sarah%20Brightman">Sarah Brightman</a>. The theme song was originally going to be a song called "So much love, so far away (Tanto amor, tan lejos)" written by Cuban singer-songwriter <a href="Jon%20Secada">Jon Secada</a> and Peruvian singer-songwriter <a href="Gian%20Marco">Gian Marco</a> under production from Cuban producer <a href="Emilio%20Estefan%20Jr.">Emilio Estefan Jr.</a> from <a href="EMI">EMI</a>.
Torch relay.
The design of the 2008 <a href="Olympic%20Torch">Olympic Torch</a> was based on traditional scrolls and used a traditional Chinese design known as the "Propitious Clouds" (祥云). The torch was designed to remain lit in 65 km/h (40 mph) winds, and in rain of up to 50 mm (2 in) per hour.
The relay, with the theme "Journey of Harmony", was met with protests and demonstrations by pro-Tibet supporters throughout its journey. It lasted 130 days and carried the torch —the longest distance of any Olympic torch relay since the tradition began at the <a href="1936%20Berlin%20Games">1936 Berlin Games</a>. The torch relay was described as a "public relations disaster" for China by "<a href="USA%20Today">USA Today</a>", with protests against China's human rights record, particularly focused on <a href="2008%20Tibetan%20unrest">Tibet</a>. The IOC subsequently barred future Olympics organizers from staging international torch relays.
The relay began 24 March 2008, in <a href="Olympia%2C%20Greece">Olympia, Greece</a>. From there, it traveled across Greece to <a href="Panathinaiko%20Stadium">Panathinaiko Stadium</a> in Athens, and then to Beijing, arriving on 31 March. From Beijing, the torch followed a route passing through every continent except <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>. The torch visited cities on the <a href="Silk%20Road">Silk Road</a>, symbolizing ancient links between China and the rest of the world. A total of 21,880 torchbearers were selected from around the world by various organizations and entities.
The international portion of the relay was problematic. The month-long world tour encountered wide-scale anti-Chinese protests. After trouble in London involving attempts by protesters to put out the flame, the torch was extinguished in Paris the following day. The American leg in San Francisco on 9 April was altered without prior warning to avoid such disturbances, although there were still demonstrations along the original route. The relay was further delayed and simplified after the <a href="2008%20Sichuan%20earthquake">2008 Sichuan earthquake</a> hit <a href="western%20China">western China</a>.
The flame was <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20summit%20of%20Mt.%20Everest">carried to the top of Mount Everest</a> on a long "highway" scaling the Tibetan side of the mountain, built especially for the relay. The $19.7 million blacktop project spanned from <a href="Tingri%20County">Tingri County</a> of <a href="Xigaz%C3%AA%20Prefecture">Xigazê Prefecture</a> to the <a href="Everest%20Base%20Camp">Everest Base Camp</a>. In March 2008, China banned mountaineers from climbing its side of Mount Everest, and later persuaded the Nepalese government to close their side as well, officially citing environmental concerns. It also reflected concerns by the Chinese government that Tibet activists might try to disrupt its plans to carry the Olympic torch up the world's tallest peak.
The originally proposed route would have taken the torch through <a href="Taipei">Taipei</a> after leaving <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> and before heading for Hong Kong. However, the government of <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> (then led by the <a href="Taiwan%20independence">independence</a>-leaning <a href="Democratic%20Progressive%20Party">Democratic Progressive Party</a>) objected to this proposal, claiming that this route would make the portion of the relay in Taiwan appear to be part of the torch's domestic journey through China, rather than a leg on the international route. This dispute, as well as Chinese demands that the <a href="flag%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20China">flag</a> and the <a href="National%20Anthem%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20China">national anthem of the Republic of China</a> be banned along the route led the government of Taiwan to reject the proposal that it be part of the relay route. The two sides of the Taiwan Strait subsequently blamed each other for injecting politics into the event.
Calendar.
In the following calendar for the 2008 Summer Olympics, each blue box represents an event competition, such as a qualification round, on that day. The yellow boxes represent days during which medal-awarding finals for a sport were held. Each bullet in these boxes is an event final, the number of bullets per box representing the number of finals that were contested on that day. On the left, the calendar lists each sport with events held during the Games, and at the right how many gold medals were won in that sport. There is a key at the top of the calendar to aid the reader.
Olympic and world records.
125 <a href="Olympic%20record">Olympic record</a>s including 37 <a href="world%20records">world records</a> were set in various events at the Games. In swimming, sixty-five <a href="List%20of%20Olympic%20records%20in%20swimming">Olympic swimming records</a> including 25 <a href="List%20of%20world%20records%20in%20swimming">world records</a> were broken due to the use of the <a href="LZR%20Racer">LZR Racer</a>, a specialized swimming suit developed by <a href="NASA">NASA</a> and the <a href="Australian%20Institute%20of%20Sport">Australian Institute of Sport</a>. Only two swimming Olympic records remained intact after the Games.
Games.
Opening ceremony.
The opening ceremony officially began at 8:00 pm <a href="China%20Standard%20Time">China Standard Time</a> (<a href="UTC%2B8">UTC+8</a>) on 8 August 2008 in the <a href="Beijing%20National%20Stadium">Beijing National Stadium</a>. The number 8 is associated with prosperity and confidence in <a href="Numbers%20in%20Chinese%20culture">Chinese culture</a>, and here it was a triple eight for the date and one extra for time (close to 08:08:08 pm). The ceremony was co-directed by Chinese filmmaker <a href="Zhang%20Yimou">Zhang Yimou</a> and Chinese choreographer <a href="Zhang%20Jigang">Zhang Jigang</a> and featured a cast of over 15,000 performers. The ceremony lasted over four hours and was reported to have cost over US$100 million to produce. <a href="UNGA">UNGA</a> President <a href="Miguel%20d%E2%80%99Escoto">Miguel d’Escoto</a> and leaders from 105 countries attended this ceremony.
A rich assembly of ancient Chinese art and culture dominated the ceremony. It opened with the beating of <a href="Fou%20%28instrument%29">Fou</a> drums for the countdown. Subsequently, a giant <a href="scroll">scroll</a> was unveiled and became the show's centerpiece. The official song of the 2008 Olympics, titled "<a href="You%20and%20Me%20%28theme%20song%29">You and Me</a>," was performed by Britain's <a href="Sarah%20Brightman">Sarah Brightman</a> and China's <a href="Liu%20Huan">Liu Huan</a>, on a large spinning rendition of the globe. On the parade of nations section, the <a href="Greece%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Greek</a> team, which hosted the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">previous games</a>, enters first in honour of its status as the Olympic birthplace. They were led by judoka <a href="Ilias%20Iliadis">Ilias Iliadis</a>. Meanwhile, the <a href="China%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Chinese</a> team enters last as the host country, led by <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a>'s <a href="Houston%20Rockets">Houston Rockets</a> superstar <a href="Yao%20Ming">Yao Ming</a> and <a href="2008%20Sichuan%20earthquake">earthquake</a> survivor Lin Hao, who was just 9 years old. The last recipient in the Olympic Torch relay, former Chinese <a href="gymnastics">gymnast</a> <a href="Li%20Ning">Li Ning</a> ignited the <a href="cauldron">cauldron</a>, after being suspended into the air by wires and completing a lap of the National Stadium at roof height.
The opening ceremony was lauded by spectators and various international presses as "spectacular" and "spellbinding". Hein Verbruggen, chairman of the IOC Coordination Commission for the XXIX Olympiad, called the ceremony "a grand, unprecedented success."
Sports.
The program for the Beijing Games was quite similar to that of the 2004 Summer Olympics held in Athens. There were 28 sports and 302 events at the 2008 Games. Nine new events were held, including two from the new <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">cycling</a> discipline of <a href="BMX">BMX</a>. Women competed in the <a href="steeplechase%20%28athletics%29">steeplechase</a> for the first time. <a href="Open%20water%20swimming">Open water swimming</a> events for men and women, over the distance of , were added to the swimming discipline. Team events (men and women) in table tennis replaced the doubles events. In <a href="fencing">fencing</a>, the women's team foil and women's team saber replaced men's team foil and women's team <a href="%C3%A9p%C3%A9e">épée</a>. Two sports were open only to men, <a href="Baseball%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">baseball</a> and <a href="Boxing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">boxing</a>, while one sport and one discipline were open only to women, <a href="Softball%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">softball</a> and <a href="Synchronized%20swimming%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">synchronized swimming</a>. <a href="Equestrian%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Equestrian</a> and <a href="Badminton%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">mixed badminton</a> are the only sports in which men and women compete together, although three events in the <a href="Sailing%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Sailing</a> allowed the opportunity for both males and female participants. However, only male participants took part in all three events.

In addition to the official Olympic sports, the Beijing Organizing Committee was given special dispensation by the IOC to run a <a href="wushu%20%28sport%29">wushu</a> competition in tandem with the Games. The <a href="2008%20Beijing%20Wushu%20Tournament">2008 Beijing Wushu Tournament</a> saw 128 athletes from 43 countries participate, with medals awarded in 15 separate events; however, these were not to be added to the official medal tally since Wushu was not on the official program of the 2008 Summer Olympics.
Closing ceremony.
The 2008 Summer Olympics Closing Ceremony concluded the Beijing Games on 24 August 2008. It began at 8:00 pm China Standard Time (UTC+8) and took place at the Beijing National Stadium.
The Ceremony included the handover of the Games from Beijing to London. <a href="Guo%20Jinlong">Guo Jinlong</a>, the <a href="Mayor%20of%20Beijing">Mayor of Beijing</a> handed over the <a href="Olympic%20flag">Olympic flag</a> to the <a href="Mayor%20of%20London">Mayor of London</a> <a href="Boris%20Johnson">Boris Johnson</a>, followed by a performance organized by <a href="London%20Organising%20Committee%20of%20the%20Olympic%20and%20Paralympic%20Games">London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games</a>. This presentation included performances by guitarist <a href="Jimmy%20Page">Jimmy Page</a> and recording artist <a href="Leona%20Lewis">Leona Lewis</a>. Footballer <a href="David%20Beckham">David Beckham</a> was also featured during London's presentation.
Medal table.
Of the 204 nations that participated in the 2008 Games, 87 earned medals and 54 of those won at least one gold medal, both of these figures setting new records for Olympic Games. There were 117 participating countries that did not win any medals. Athletes from <a href="China%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">China</a> won the highest number of gold medals of any nation at these Games, with 48, thus making China the seventh nation to rank top in the medal table in the history of the modern Olympics, along with the <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%20Olympics">United States</a> (fifteen times), <a href="France%20at%20the%20Olympics">France</a> (in 1900), <a href="Great%20Britain%20at%20the%20Olympics">Great Britain</a> (in 1908), <a href="Germany%20at%20the%20Olympics">Germany</a> (in 1936), the <a href="Soviet%20Union%20at%20the%20Olympics">Soviet Union</a> (six times), and the <a href="Unified%20Team%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">Unified Team</a> (in 1992).
The <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">United States</a> team won the most medals overall, with 112. <a href="Afghanistan%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="Mauritius%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Mauritius</a>, <a href="Sudan%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Sudan</a>, <a href="Tajikistan%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Tajikistan</a> and <a href="Togo%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Togo</a> won their first ever Olympic medals. <a href="Mongolia%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Mongolia</a> (which previously held the record for most medals without a gold) and <a href="Panama%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Panama</a> won their first gold medals. Four members of the water polo team from <a href="Serbia%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Serbia</a> won the first medal for their country under its new name, having previously won medals representing <a href="Yugoslavia%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics">Yugoslavia</a> and <a href="Serbia%20and%20Montenegro%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics">Serbia and Montenegro</a>.
American swimmer <a href="Michael%20Phelps">Michael Phelps</a> won a total of eight gold medals, more than any other athlete in a single Olympic Games, setting numerous world and Olympic records in the process. Jamaican sprinter <a href="Usain%20Bolt">Usain Bolt</a> also set records in several different events, completing the 100 m final with a time of 9.69 seconds, beating his own previous world record. Gymnast <a href="Nastia%20Liukin">Nastia Liukin</a> won the all-around gold medal in artistic gymnastics, becoming the third American female to do so, following in the footsteps of <a href="Mary%20Lou%20Retton">Mary Lou Retton</a> in <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984</a> and <a href="Carly%20Patterson">Carly Patterson</a> in <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004</a>.

Participating National Olympic Committees.
All but one of the 205 recognized <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a>s (NOCs) that existed participated in the 2008 Summer Olympics, the exception being <a href="Brunei%20at%20the%20Olympics">Brunei</a>. Three countries participated in the Olympic Games for their first time: the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a>, <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> and <a href="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>.
While not a full member recognized by the IOC and thus not allowed to compete formally in the Olympics, the <a href="Macau%20Sports%20and%20Olympic%20Committee">Macau Sports and Olympic Committee</a> sent a delegation to participate in the <a href="Wushu%20Tournament%20Beijing%202008">Wushu Tournament Beijing 2008</a>, being the only unrecognized <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a> to have taken part in the 2008 Summer Olympics. It also coordinated efforts with the <a href="Chinese%20Olympic%20Committee">Chinese Olympic Committee</a> to organize the torch relay through Macau.
The Marshall Islands and Tuvalu gained National Olympic Committee status in 2006 and 2007 respectively, and 2008 was the first Games in which they were eligible to participate. The states of <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, which participated at the 2004 Games jointly as <a href="Serbia%20and%20Montenegro">Serbia and Montenegro</a>, competed separately for the first time. The Montenegrin Olympic Committee was accepted as a new National Olympic Committee in 2007. Neighboring <a href="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, however, did not participate. After the declaration of independence in Kosovo, the IOC specified requirements that Kosovo needs to meet before being recognized by the IOC; most notably, it has to be recognized as independent by the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>. However, it has since been recognised by the IOC in 2014 without fulfilling this criteria and made its debut in the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympic%20Games">2016 games</a>.
More than 100 sovereigns, heads of state and heads of government as well as 170 Ministers of Sport attended the Beijing Olympic Games.
National participation changes.
Athletes from the <a href="Republic%20of%20China">Republic of China</a> (Taiwan) competed at the 2008 Games as <a href="Chinese%20Taipei">Chinese Taipei</a> (TPE) under the <a href="Chinese%20Taipei%20Olympic%20flag">Chinese Taipei Olympic flag</a> and used the <a href="National%20Banner%20Song">National Banner Song</a> as their official anthem. The participation of Taiwan was briefly in doubt because of disagreements over the name of their team in the Chinese language and concerns about Taiwan marching in the Opening Ceremony next to the special administrative region of Hong Kong. A compromise on the naming was reached, and Taiwan was referred to during the Games as "Chinese Taipei," rather than "Taipei, China," as the mainland China government had proposed. In addition, the <a href="Central%20African%20Republic%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Central African Republic</a> was placed between Chinese Taipei and the Special Administrative Regions during the march of nations.
Starting in 2005, <a href="North%20Korea">North Korea</a> and South Korea held meetings to discuss the possibility of sending a united team to the 2008 Olympics. The proposal failed, because of disagreements about how athletes would be chosen; North Korea was demanding a certain percentage representation for its athletes. A subsequent attempt to broker an agreement for the two nations to walk together during the March of Nations failed as well, despite their having done so during the 2000 and 2004 Games.
On 24 July 2008, the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) banned <a href="Iraq%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">Iraq</a> from competing in the 2008 Olympic Summer Games because of "political interference by the government in sports." The IOC reversed its decision five days later and allowed the nation to compete after a pledge by Iraq to ensure "the independence of its national Olympics panel" by instituting fair elections before the end of November. In the meantime, Iraq's Olympic Organization was to be run by "an interim committee proposed by its national sports federations and approved by the IOC."
<a href="Brunei">Brunei Darussalam</a> was due to take part in the 2008 Summer Olympic Games. However, they were disqualified on 8 August, having failed to register either of their two athletes. The IOC spokeswoman Emmanuelle Moreau said in a statement that "it is a great shame and very sad for the athletes who lose out because of the decision by their team not to register them. The IOC tried up until the last minute, midday Friday 8 August 2008, the day of the official opening, to have them register, but to no avail." Brunei's Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports issued a press release stating that their decision not to participate was due to an injury to one of their athletes.
<a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a> announced on 9 August 2008, that it was considering withdrawing from the Beijing Olympic Games because of the <a href="2008%20South%20Ossetia%20war">2008 South Ossetia war</a>, but it went on to compete while the conflict was still ongoing.
Participation of athletes with disabilities.
South African swimmer <a href="Natalie%20du%20Toit">Natalie du Toit</a>, whose left leg was amputated following a motor scooter accident, qualified to compete at the Beijing Olympics. The five time gold medalist at the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Paralympics">Athens Paralympics in 2004</a> made history by becoming the first <a href="amputee">amputee</a> to qualify for the Olympic Games since <a href="Oliv%C3%A9r%20Halassy">Olivér Halassy</a> in 1936. She was able to compete in the Olympics rather than the Paralympics because she does not use a prosthetic leg while swimming. Polish athlete <a href="Natalia%20Partyka">Natalia Partyka</a>, who was born without a right forearm, competed in Table Tennis in the 2008 Summer Olympics and 2008 Paralympic Games.
Mascots.
The mascots of the 2008 Summer Olympics are the Fuwa, created by Han Meilin (韩美林). The mascots consisted of Beibei, a fish, Jingjing, a panda, Huanhuan, an Olympic flame, Yingying, a Tibetan antelope, and Nini, a sand martin kite. If combined, it would being "Beijing Huanying Ni" ("北京欢迎你") or "Beijing Welcomes You", which is a theme (and a song) for welcoming the athletes to Beijing several months before. They were featured in an animated cartoon, 100-episode <a href="The%20Olympic%20Adventures%20of%20Fuwa">The Olympic Adventures of Fuwa</a>, launched in 2007, a year before the games.
Concerns and controversies.
A variety of concerns over the Games, or China's hosting of the Games, had been expressed by various entities, including claims that China violated its <a href="Beijing%202008%20Olympic%20bid">pledge</a> to allow open media access, various claims of human rights violations, its alleged continuous support of repressive regimes (such as Zimbabwe, Myanmar, Sudan, and North Korea), air pollution in both the city of Beijing and environs, proposed <a href="Olympic%20boycotts">boycotts</a>, warnings of the possibility that the Beijing Olympics could be targeted by terrorist groups, disruption from Tibetan separatist protesters, and religious persecutions.
There were also claims that several members of China's women's gymnastics team, including double gold medal winner <a href="He%20Kexin">He Kexin</a>, were too young to compete under the <a href="International%20Gymnastics%20Federation">International Gymnastics Federation</a>'s rules for Olympic eligibility, but all were exonerated after an official IOC investigation.
Collectively, the Beijing Olympics are associated with a variety of problematic topics: the ecological impact, residential displacement due to construction, treatment of migrant workers, the government's political stance on Tibet, etc. In the lead-up to the Olympics, the government allegedly issued guidelines to the local media for their reporting during the Games: most political issues not directly related to the Olympics were to be downplayed; topics such as pro-Tibetan independence and East Turkestan movements were not to be reported on, as were food safety issues such as "cancer-causing mineral water". As the <a href="2008%20Chinese%20milk%20scandal">2008 Chinese milk scandal</a> broke in September 2008, there was widespread speculation that China's desire for a perfect Games may have been a factor contributing towards the delayed recall of contaminated <a href="infant%20formula">infant formula</a>.
The 2008 Olympics were hit by a number of doping scandals before and after the Games had commenced. Since seven Russian track and field stars were suspended just before the start of the Games for allegedly tampering with their urine samples, only five of the seven who were due to take part could participate. Eleven Greek weightlifters also failed tests in the run up to the Games and the entire Bulgarian weightlifting team had to withdraw after eleven of their weightlifters also failed tests. A small number of athletes from other nations also failed pre-Games tests.
Legacy.
The 2008 Summer Olympics have been generally accepted by the world's media as a <a href="logistics">logistical</a> success. Many of the worst fears about the Games failed to materialize: no terrorists struck Beijing; no athlete protested at the podium (though Swedish wrestler <a href="Ara%20Abrahamian">Ara Abrahamian</a> tossed his bronze medal in disgust over judging); and the air quality, despite being the worst in Olympics history, was not as bad as many had feared beforehand – due largely to favorable weather patterns.
Many in China viewed the Olympics as "an affirmation of a single <a href="nationalism">nationalistic</a> dream" and saw protests during the international torch relay as an insult to China. The Games also bolstered domestic support for the Chinese government, and for the policies of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20China">Communist Party</a>, giving rise to concerns that the Olympics would give the state more leverage to suppress political <a href="dissent">dissent</a>, at least temporarily. Efforts to quell any unrest before and during the Games also contributed to a rapid expansion in the size and political clout of China's <a href="Ministry%20of%20Public%20Security%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">internal security forces</a>, and this growth continued through the following years. Reports also indicated that the Olympics boosted the political careers of pro-Beijing politicians in Hong Kong, as many Chinese gold medal winners campaigned on behalf of the pro-Beijing <a href="The%20Democratic%20Alliance%20for%20the%20Betterment%20and%20Progress%20of%20Hong%20Kong">DAB</a> during the <a href="2008%20Hong%20Kong%20legislative%20election">2008 election</a>, although any trend towards greater identification by <a href="Hong%20Kong%20people">Hong Kongers</a> with Mainland China appears to have been short-lived.
The <a href="Economic%20history%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">long-term economic impact</a> of the Games on China and Beijing, in particular, is not yet clear. Some sectors of the economy may have benefited from the influx of tourists. Other sectors such as manufacturing lost revenue because of plant closings related to the government's efforts to improve air quality. Four years after the Games, many of the specially constructed facilities were underused or even deserted. It is generally expected by economists that there will be no lasting effects on Beijing's economy from the Games.
One 2009 study found that countries that host the Olympics experience a significant boost in trade, but this is also the case for countries which merely bid to host: "The benefit, in other words, came from the signal that a country was open for business, not from the spending itself."
Seven years after the 2008 Games, Beijing was awarded the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>. It will thus be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Games.
